Although I am sure to take some heat for this, my feelings have always been
that mounts belong on swords and not in boxes. However, there are mounts and
then there are swords and they should be at the same level if put together.
Still, your approach is often taken everywhere, including Japan.

 

Gordon

Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] shinsa question

 

Gordon - 

A personal dilemma. Last March I've purchased a beautiful mumei katana with
fantastic (really!) horimono. It came with koshirae which had damage. I've
had the sword put into shirazaya and a tsunagi made for the koshirae with
repairs, on-going. Because the tsuka wrapping was literally falling apart,
the fuchi/kashira and menuki were removed and therefore, able to be examined
in-hand. The menuki are solid gold "dragons" which are super! The
fuchi/kashira (mumei) are even more fine and really do cry for shinsa with
an eye toward Goto. The kozuka/kogai looked "mainline Goto" but drew
(reportedly) a generic "Goto den" call from the NBTHK. 

My dilemma, should these wonderful fitting be placed back on the sword or be
kept seperately and "boxed" for individual preservation and appreciation. I
say "dilemma" but in all honesty my choice has been made; they will be boxed
for individual in-hand appreciation. So, should I feel bad to have in a
sense "destroyed" a koshirae or should I feel good to have discovered these
wonderful kodogu. Granted, the koshirae was not truly a (and I hate this
expression) "matching" koshirae and was really "put together" by it pre-war
owner. Yes, I'll keep the saya and (unmounted) tsuka together with a tsunagi
but it seems such a waste to put these beautiful fitting back on it where
they can be damaged (f/k, kozuka/kogai) or hidden under ito (menuki). 

After saying all this I'm not too sure where I'm going with it, but my point
might be that there is a time to "preserve" a koshirae" and a time to not
worry about it. 

Ron
STL

  I think if you look at museum collections in Japan, the answer is there.
  They do not touch anything no matter the condition. If the wrap is coming
  off, it is coming off. They may add something to secure menuki and such to
  keep them in place - typically thread. The same goes with lacquer, it is
not
  touched. Thus, the standards for shinsa are the same. I am pretty sure
this
  is the case with the NBTHK as well. So, what to do to repair something? If
  you want to keep the piece original and unaltered, you must have all new
  mounts made and you set aside the original pieces. I know this may seem to
  be unreasonable, but those are the very high standards that have been
  maintained at shinsa and in museums. I think the same holds true for
antique
  firearms. Re-blued barrels, re-done stocks and what not seriously harm the
  value of the piece. Thus, such alterations should not be done lightly.



  Jim, care to comment?



  Gordon

  <robsongo@...> writes:

  > Hi Cary and Milt,
  > This is good timing as I wanted to warn Chicago shinsa attendees about
  > submitting koshirae. If you submit a tsuka, then the same will apply as
  with
  > the NBTHK. Make sure that the tsuka has not been re-wrapped in the last
  100
  > or so years - that means it is no longer antique and will be bounced.
  Entire
  > koshirae will be judged based on authenticity and age of all the pieces,
  > i.e. nothing replaced, re-wrapped or re-lacquered. Also, if pieces are
  > mumei, they will not be attributed. You must submit the pieces
separately
  > for that. If all or some of the pieces are signed, then they will be
  > authenticated. 

  In the case of damaged koshirae, is this a bouncable offense, in which
  case once something is damaged it becomes unpaperable?

  - darcy
